urn:contentItem:6GF0-5HP3-SFWC-X2P3-00000-00Air quality alerts in place for 10 states due to Canadian wildfires2025-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & CANADA NEWSAir quality alerts in place for 10 states due to Canadian wildfiresSarah Fortinsky

The National Weather Serviceannounced air quality alerts in 10 states Tuesday as smoke from the Canadian wildfires continues to spread across the U.S.border.

The alerts come as the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre lists 746 active fires Tuesday morning, including 199 that were considered out of control. On Monday morning, 743 ac tive fires were listed, including 298 that were out of control.

All of Wisconsin remains under air quality alert, with some parts placed under “red” alert, meaning some members of the public may experience adverse health effects; and other parts of the state are placed under “orange” alert, meaning air quality may be “unhealthy” for sensitive groups.

The smoke is expected to recirculate and effect northeast Wisconsin the most. The alert will remain in place until noon CDT Tuesday.

Connecticut’s Fairfield, New Haven and Middlesex counties are under “orange” alert for Tuesday.

Several cities in Indiana were placed under “orange” alert for all of Tuesday until midnight, including Gary, Hammond, Merrillville, Portage, Valparaiso, Chesterton, Roselawn, Kentland, Morocco, Rensselaer and DeMotte.

Massachusetts was placed under “orange” alert from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. EDT Tuesday. The alert affects parts of the Berkshires, including the cities of Dalton, Hancock, Pittsfield, Florida, North Adams, Sandisfield, Great Barrington and South Egremont.

Minnesota’s northeast region is under an “orange” alert until noon CDT Wednesday. Periods of low air quality are possible for the southeast and north-central parts of the state, as well.

Michigan counties placed under “orange” alert for Tuesday are Chippewa, Mackinac, Emmet, Cheboygan, Presque Isle, Leelanau, Antrim, Otsego, Montmorency, Alpena, Benzie, Grand Traverse, Kalkaska, Crawford, Oscoda, Alcona, Manistee, Wexford, Missaukee, Roscommon, Ogemaw, Iosco, Gladwin and Arenac.

New York is under “orange” alert for all of Tuesday until midnight EDT in several counties: New York, Bronx, Kings, Queens, Richmond, Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Putnam.

New Jersey’s Bergen, Passaic, Hudson, Essex and Union counties are under “orange” alert until midnight.

Eastern Pennsylvania was placed under an “orange” alert for all of Tuesday until midnight.

Vermont’s Bennington and Windham counties are under “orange” alert until midnight.


For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to The Hill.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RFH3-S6GH-N0C3-00000-00Minister Graça Carvalho: Douro International fire "is an environmental and landscape catastrophe"2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisMinister Graça Carvalho: Douro International fire "is an environmental and landscape catastrophe"


The Minister for the Environment, Maria da Graça Carvalho, today classified the fire that broke out on August 15 in the Douro International as an environmental and landscape catastrophe, after a visit to this protected area.
"It's an environmental and landscape catastrophe, because it's a natural park that is a pearl and is still beautiful, but it has a vast area that has had a huge impact on the more than five thousand hectares that have burned in this protected area," she told journalists at the Carrascalinho viewpoint, in the municipality of Freixo de Espada à Cinta, which was the most affected by the flames.


Maria da Graça Carvalho also said that now is the time to look to the future and try to propose the potential of the Douro International Natural Park (PNDI), which is the second largest protected area in the country.
The responsibilities of the Ministry of the Environment include all the emergency interventions, such as preventing landslides, of which there are many, preventing the ashes from contaminating the water that supplies the population and which are being monitored by the Institute for Nature Conservation and Forests (ICNF) and the Portuguese Environment Agency (APA).
Read also Fires: record sums fail to prevent second largest area to have burned in 20 years Fires: Support for farmers to start arriving next week, says minister
The minister said that immediate aid to restore productive potential is underway, especially in agriculture, under the supervision of the Ministry of Economy and the Ministry of Agriculture.
The minister also stressed that there is a concern to restore the entire ecosystem of the PNDI, both in terms of fauna and flora and all biodiversity.
"When we do this [environmental] restoration, our concern is to reduce future risk based on the best scientific practices that are used in other countries, and the lessons learned here in Portugal. There are areas like the Alvão Natural Park or the Peneda-Gerês National Park that have hardwood trees that act as a buffer against the advance of fires," said Maria da Graça Carvalho.
Now the bet to recover the burnt area in the PNDI is to plant tree species that are more resilient and resistant to flames.
In the field of birdlife, the recovery of European projects underway in these protected areas also caught the attention of the minister, such as the case of the Iberian program "LIFE Aegypius Return", which aims to safeguard the black vulture (\'Aegypius monachus\') and where nests, an acclimatization station and other structures were destroyed, causing losses of more than 30,000 euros in this environmental initiative alone.
"We will do everything we can to get this Iberian black vulture recovery project back on track."
The Environment Minister stressed that it will take several years for the ecosystem affected by the fire in the Douro International to return to its full potential.
"For these cases, direct aid [funding] has already been regulated, which provides for a contact for each of the protected areas affected by the fires, involving the municipalities, ICNF, APA and the Climate Agency," she said.
Read Also Residents in areas affected by fires with extended deadlines for paying taxes Negócios asks. Majority "flunks" government action on fire management Diploma with support for people and companies affected by the fires comes into force
The Douro International fire broke out on August 15 in Poiares, in the municipality of Freixo de Espada à Cinta, the worst affected, and soon spread to the neighboring municipalities of Torre de Moncorvo and Mogadouro, leaving a trail of destruction in pastures and crops such as olive groves, almond groves, vineyards, orange groves, forests and beehives.
According to provisional figures from the GNR, around 12,000 hectares burned in the municipalities of Freixo de Espada à Cinta, Torre de Moncorvo and Mogadouro, in a fire that had around 400 operatives on the ground and no air resources due to the weather conditions.
Data from the provisional national report from the Forest Fire Information Management System (SIGF) to which the Lusa news agency had access indicates that, as of August 24, 11,697 hectares have been burnt in the fire that started in the municipality of Freixo de Espada à Cinta.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RFH3-S6GH-N0BW-00000-00Alarming situation: Spain and Portugal dominate the list of hectares burned by forest fires2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisAlarming situation: Spain and Portugal dominate the list of hectares burned by forest fires


So far this year, the area burned in the European Union (EU) has exceeded one million hectares, the worst figure since records have been kept, largely due to the intense fires in August in the Iberian Peninsula that left thousands of people dead, thousands evacuated and protected areas razed to the ground.
With one month left in the fire season, the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), counts 1 million 16 thousand 425 hectares (ha) burned, surpassing the 993 thousand 558 ha of 2017, so far the record since records began in 2006.


Spain and Portugal alone concentrate more than 60% of the area razed by fire in the 27 countries. In the Spanish case, fires have devastated 377 thousand 234 ha, 37 % of the total, while in Portugal the figure amounts to 260 thousand 358 ha, 25 %.
The month began with an intense heat wave that was felt throughout southern Europe, but especially in the two Iberian countries. In Spain it lasted 16 days and became the strongest since records have been kept, with an anomaly of 4.6 degrees.
According to a report released Friday by the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet), the spring of this year - "very wet" in much of the peninsula - favored an extraordinary growth of vegetation that, after a dry and warm June and July, became fuel for the fires.
The flames not only devastated the territory, but also triggered polluting gases. According to EFFIS, between January 1 and August 26, 38.37 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) were released as a result of the fires, more than three times as much as in the same period in 2024 (11.46 million).
Copernicus Atmospheric Monitoring Service (CAMS) scientist Mark Parrington called the emissions from the Spanish and Portuguese fires during August "exceptional" and warned that the large amounts of smoke and PM2.5 particles caused a "serious deterioration of air quality" in the Iberian Peninsula and parts of France.
Spain and Portugal most affected
In Spain, regions such as Castilla y León (center-north), Galicia (northwest) or Extremadura (west) have been the hardest hit by forest fires which, in recent weeks, registered more than twenty serious outbreaks active at the same time.
The fires have caused at least eight deaths so far this year and, in August alone, forced the evacuation of more than 35,000 people, burned villages, protected natural areas or cut roads and railways.
The landscape of Las Médulas (León), where the largest open-pit gold mine of the Roman Empire is located, classified by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site, has been engulfed in flames that took with them some of its centenary chestnut trees.
Areas of the Picos de Europa National Park were also burned and pilgrims walking the Camino de Santiago on stretches close to the fires were affected.
Portugal, although with fewer total hectares burned, is the EU country with the highest percentage of territory consumed by the flames, 2.83 %, concentrated mainly in the central and northern regions.
The wave of fires left four deaths, evacuations and also affected natural areas, with a fire in the Douro International Natural Park, in the north, and a fire in the area of Arganil (center) devastated more than 64,400 hectares, becoming one of the largest fires in its history.
The powerful heat wave this August also favored the advance of fires in countries such as Albania and Greece, where fatalities and evictions were recorded.
In Greece, with 46,783 hectares burned, an area much smaller than in other years when the figure exceeded 100,000 hectares, the heat and winds led to the outbreak of 152 fires in 24 hours in the middle of the month.
The situation in the northern Peloponnese, with outbreaks out of control, forced the evacuation of some 7,500 people and, days earlier, a fire in the southeast of Athens left one dead.
The European Space Agency (ESA) recalled last Wednesday that the long-term challenge is that these phenomena are expected to become more frequent and intense as the climate crisis worsens.

urn:contentItem:6GMP-SNV3-S40J-44X2-00000-00Living smarter means taking solution-focused action together: Muskoka Watershed Council2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisOPINION/COLUMNISTSPg. 1Living smarter means taking solution-focused action together: Muskoka Watershed CouncilLinda Mathers

In 1972, I sat in a packed Huntsville High School audience, rivetted along with my colleagues, as David Suzuki laid out the science of climate change. Using stark compelling language, he said we had 50 years to work actively and collaboratively to keep the earth from warming an additional 1.5 C and avoid the human tragedy and irreversible crisis climate heating would cause. Last month, he said it was too late; we had passed 1.5 C and our focus must shift to community resilience.

As a grandparent, I ride an emotional climate roller-coaster from despair to hope, immobility to action, fear to anger, over the world of my grandchildren's future. I know I am not alone.

Seniors are one of the largest demographics in the climate action movement. We have lived experience of the rapid acceleration of the frequency and intensity of weather extremes causing devastation. We know it is not normal for our neighbouring communities to be on forest fire evacuation alerts; nor is it normal to declare back-to-back states of emergency from extremes of ice and snow in Muskoka. We know it is not normal for us to suffer health consequences from weeks of extreme heat and air quality smoke alerts. It is not normal to watch the news and see the grief and horror of children swept away from summer camp in Texas from torrential rain and flash flooding.

Yet my grandchildren are growing up with this lived experience, their "new normal."

As adults, we see children experiencing eco-anxiety, a fear that the climate will make the planet unlivable in their future. Our grandchildren know we need to live differently, but they see adults who live as though we have all the time in the world to take action.

What gives me hope for my grandchildren's future? Talking about solution-focused action and working with like-minded people to be a community voice and a political voice.

We can eat smarter, travel smarter and heat our homes smarter. Those of us choosing EVs, heat pumps and electric yard tools are happy to share our positive experiences and talk about our significant annual savings. My neighbours have just built a net-zero home. The bike lanes on our road are heavily travelled and if it weren't for the pesky groundhog, we would have fed ourselves most of the summer. Thankfully, many local food options are now available. And the Muskoka Summit on the Environment, on Oct. 3, is a great opportunity to learn more.

Countries around the world are rapidly transitioning to renewable energy instead of burning fossil fuels; renewables just this year have surpassed gas and oil as less expensive energy sources. While many of us feel angry that our governments in Canada are increasing rather than decreasing our heat-trapping pollution, we can speak up and urge our own communities in Muskoka, like many across the country, to electrify everything and green our grid for our grandkids.

A recent ruling by the International Court of Justice, the most powerful court in the world, also gives me hope. Countries and companies who continue to subsidize and expand the exploration, extraction and burning of fossil fuels will be held financially responsible for making parts of the planet unlivable, especially for citizens of the global south. As a result, investing in fossil fuels like oil and natural gas will rapidly become a poor financial risk. Perhaps my grandchildren's governments will no longer subsidize polluting gas and oil industries, and their banks and pension plans will divest from fossil fuel companies.

What's missing still is urgent action. We responded swiftly to Trump's threat to our sovereignty and our economy with an impactful 30 per cent drop in our purchase of goods and travel to the U.S.; let's treat this climate threat to our health and economy with the same urgent action.

Let's ensure that all our grandkids enjoy a smarter, more resilient future.

urn:contentItem:6GR9-MXR3-RRRC-R46T-00000-00Postecoglou promises rapid change after getting a brutal welcome back2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisSPORTVersion:1Postecoglou promises rapid change after getting a brutal welcome backPaul Hayward

Manager given idea of his task as Forest are exposed by Arsenal thanks to Zubimendi’s double

The revolution starts on Wednesday. In Swansea. In the Carabao Cup. Nottingham Forest’s new manager Ange Postecoglou watched a predictable 3-0 defeat at Arsenal sail by and then promised immediate change in South Wales in midweek.

After a lugubrious start to his post-match briefing, Postecoglou remembered he needed to boost morale and switched tones when he was asked how long it would take to remake Forest in his image. Weeks or months? “No, mate, it won’t be months, it won’t be weeks – it’ll be Wednesday. I can’t afford to waste time,” he said. “This is not a project. This club had a strong season last year and needs to be stronger this year.

“My job is to get us to where I want us as quickly as possible. On Wednesday we’ll start seeing some real principles embedded. It won’t take long. I’m not going to let it take long to make sure we turn around.”

Swansea City have been warned. And Postecoglou has heaped pressure on himself by promising such a quick reinvention, a change of style some Forest fans may feel isn’t necessary, given how well Nuno Espírito Santo did before falling out with the club’s owner. This defeat began with Arsenal using Forest as a practice wall as they endeavour to improve their attacking play. Goals from Martín Zubimendi (two) and Viktor Gyökeres and auspicious performances from Noni Madueke and Eberechi Eze raised Arsenal’s sights while setting out the cost of what Postecoglou called “a very disruptive week for [my] players”.

An ex-Spurs manager was never going to elicit much sympathy here, so when Arsenal’s third goal went in, the home crowd sang: “Are you Tottenham in disguise?”

In his all-blue casual weekend wear, Postecoglou stood in his classic fact-finding stance: hands in pockets, eyes roaming to assess the task he took on 95 days after being sacked four and a half miles up the road.

For the second consecutive match Forest lost 3-0 to a London club, first with Nuno, then with Postecoglou. The buccaneering spirit of last season has yet to re-emerge. It’s way too soon to call it a full Forest fire but Postecoglou has inherited a mood of uncertainty and instability at one of the league’s fastest-rising clubs.

They returned from international week with one full training session to assess where Douglas Luiz, Dilane Bakwa, Arnaud Kalimuendo, Omari Hutchinson, James McAtee and Jair Cunha might fit in. Postecoglou took charge on Tuesday. Nobody rewrites a playing style in four days.

The only change he made to the side that lost 3-0 to West Ham was forced: Ola Aina’s hamstring injury opening the gate for Morato, who was hounded by Madueke on Arsenal’s right. Watching all this, Postecoglou said he would now start “pinning down some of the principles of how we want to play”.

Appointed 13 hours after Nuno’s exit, and with £180m of summer signings to sort through, he arrived with analysts obsessing over a likely tactical reinvention – from low line to high line, from “backing off to pressing hard”, as one put it; from going direct to passing through the lines.

Usually this indicates a confused identity. Successful clubs don’t generally change their core ideas with each new manager. It throws players off track. Sometimes, though, the cost of having a headstrong owner is that a manager who is performing well (in this case Nuno) leaves for reasons that have little to do with results.

Evangelos Marinakis, Forest’s undeniably headstrong owner, might call Postecoglou an upgrade, because three months ago he was hugging the Europa League trophy. His only ­victory since has been of the moral kind: the easing out at Spurs of the man who sacked him, Daniel Levy.

With Spurs last season Postecoglou finished 27 points behind Forest. He was one place off relegation in 17th, after 22 defeats in 38 games and 65 goals conceded. Tottenham’s 1-0 victory over Manchester United in the Europa League final preserved Postecoglou’s impressive trophy-winning record without dispelling the sense that his position there had become untenable.

The Europa League win, which Spurs prioritised as their league campaign succumbed to farce, came 30 years after his coaching career began at South Melbourne. That measure of his coaching ability is the one Forest fans will cling to. And at least he has Elliot Anderson, 22, a roaming, intelligent midfielder with constructive instincts. “We didn’t have a lot of the ball today, but every time he was on it, I thought he was unbelievable,” said Postecoglou. “I’m really excited to work with him. He’s still a young man. I’ve only had 48 hours with him but already I can see he’s very ambitious, wants to win, and be the best.”

A coach brought in to “win trophies”, Postecoglou has a more immediate job than that. Nuno passed a vital dressing room test. He improved the team, gave them shape and a shared identity and purpose. Recently promoted sides crave those certainties. Now Postecoglou is constructing a new path to the orchard.

It may work. Either way it will take time. But uncertainty tends not to help when Arsenal are coming at you.

urn:contentItem:6GRG-9T43-RXF2-T3J5-00000-00Petrobras and Vale appear in study blaming companies for extreme heatwaves2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisPetrobras and Vale appear in study blaming companies for extreme heatwaves


Attribution studies verify the influence of climate change on the frequency and severity of extreme events. Research published this week in the scientific journal Nature goes further: it shows how much entities and companies have contributed to the occurrence of heat waves this century.


The list is long, includes Brazil's Petrobras and Vale, and is seen as a path towards unprecedented liability for the environmental damage caused.
The first cause and effect relationship is well known: the emission of greenhouse gases, especially the burning of fossil fuels, causes global warming; the second, which is increasingly evident, is that warming makes events such as heatwaves more likely and more intense.
From 2000 to 2009, 20 times more. From 2010 to 2019, 200 times more. Events that would not occur without the emissions caused by the production of oil, gas, coal and cement.
The new study, which looks at 213 heat waves recorded between 2000 and 2023, reveals how much each of the 180 largest emitters on the planet contributed to the occurrence of these events.
The so-called "carbon majors", led by the former Soviet Union, include national entities, state-owned companies and publicly traded companies. The group is responsible for half of the increase in the intensity of heat waves since the pre-industrial era.
Depending on the emitter, the contribution to the problem is large enough to cause not one, but several extreme events. Any one of the 14 largest oil companies on the planet, for example, has emitted enough carbon to cause 50 heatwaves on its own. Petrobras is one of them.
When contacted by the report, the Brazilian state-owned company declined to comment. Even the smallest emitters in the group, write the researchers, "contributed substantially to the occurrence of heat waves".
This is the case with Vale, which said it "recognizes the relevance of studies like this" and that it will divest from the coal production cited in the text in 2022.
According to the WHO (World Health Organization), heat waves are responsible for 500,000 deaths a year. This year, they caused temperatures to rise by 2°C in unlikely places like Lapland, in northern Finland, as well as contributing to the largest forest fire in European history, with more than a million hectares devoured by fire.
In 2010, in the only Brazilian episode listed in the study, a heatwave caused 38 deaths in Nova Lima (MG), Santos and Rio de Janeiro.
Individualized accountability, the researchers write in the opening of the article, "fills an evidence gap". With the mechanism, it is possible to discriminate the contribution of each company in extreme events with scientific rigor.
Two important legal decisions in the environmental field have signaled a path towards such evidence. In July, the International Court of Justice, linked to the UN, declared that climate change is "an urgent and existential threat". According to the opinion presented in The Hague (Netherlands), "States have a legal obligation to protect the climate system from anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions".
In a more practical case, in May, the appeals court in Hamm, western Germany, rejected a lawsuit brought by a Peruvian farmer against the energy company RWE, but set a precedent: "If there is a threat of damage, the party responsible for the CO2 emissions may be obliged to take preventive measures (...) [or] to bear the costs in proportion to its share of emissions."
Two of the world's largest oil companies, the American ExxonMobil and the Saudi state-owned Saudi Aramco, the study shows, made 51 of the 213 heatwaves analyzed 10,000 times more likely. Not together, but alone. Questioned by the British newspaper The Guardian, the two companies declined to comment on the researchers' conclusions.
"For some time, it has been argued that any individual contributor to climate change was making too small or too diffuse a contribution to be associated with any specific impact. And this emerging science, in this paper and others, is showing that's not true," Chris Callahan, a climate scientist at Indiana University, who is not involved in the research, told the Associated Press.
Sonia Seneviratne, a professor at the Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich, one of the main names to sign the study, also draws attention to the possibilities that the new method creates in the environmental sector.
"Being able to trace the contribution of these individual emitters and quantify their contribution to the problem can be very useful in establishing potential liability," he said.
Attribution studies use climate models to compare the conditions of the period analyzed with those of the pre-industrial era (1850-1900), thus verifying the influence of global warming. In the current study, heat waves had an average increase of 1.4°C from 2000 to 2009, 1.7°C from 2009 to 2019 and 2.2°C from 2020 to 2023.
THE OTHER SIDE
Cited in the study published in Nature magazine, Vale commented: "Vale recognizes the relevance of studies like this and remains committed to decarbonization, having achieved 27% reduction in scope 1 and 2 emissions in 2024 compared to the base year of 2017. The company points out that the emissions included in the study refer to the period in which it produced coal, a business from which it divested in 2022, in line with its ambition to become a leader in low-carbon mining."
Also quoted in the article, Petrobras had not responded by the time this report was published.

urn:contentItem:6FXG-XY73-RV9W-Y30F-00000-00New Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences Study Findings Have Been Published by Researchers at Akdeniz University (Investigation of InSAR Coherence Data and Frequency Ratio for Analyzing Forest Fires: A Case Study of ...)2025-05-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - PHOTOGRAMMETRY REMOTE SENSING AND SPATIAL INFORMATION SCIENCESNew Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences Study Findings Have Been Published by Researchers at Akdeniz University (Investigation of InSAR Coherence Data and Frequency Ratio for Analyzing Forest Fires: A Case Study of ...)


2025 MAY 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Research findings on photogrammetry remote sensing and spatial information sciences are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting out of Akdeniz University by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Optical sensors are widely used in the detection and analysis of forest fires. However, in regions affected by dense smoke clouds during fires or areas with persistently cloudy weather due to climatic conditions, conducting analyses using optical imagery becomes challenging."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Akdeniz University: "Therefore, this study focuses on the detection and monitoring of forest fires using InSAR Coherence data. Prior to the fire detection/monitoring analyses, forest fire incidents in the Turkey/Izmir region between 2012 and 2024 were collected from the NASA FIRMS platform. In addition to these data, maps of slope, aspect, curvature, and drainage were derived from the DEM of the Izmir region. Urban areas in Izmir were identified using CORINE data, road networks were obtained from OSM datasets, temperature and wind data were retrieved from ERA-5 datasets, and precipitation data were sourced from the CHIRPS dataset. Using these collected parameters, forest fire susceptibility maps for the Izmir region were generated through the Frequency Ratio method. The resulting map revealed a direct correlation between increasing slope and heightened forest fire susceptibility in the region. Additionally, the urban parameter demonstrated a high frequency ratio in the analyses, indicating its contribution to fire risk, and areas near settlements were observed to exhibit high-risk levels on the map. Following the generation of the fire susceptibility map, a forest fire in the Izmir/Yamanlar Mountain area was investigated using the InSAR Coherence method."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The analyses showed that forest fires can be detected/monitored through the changes observed in InSAR Coherence histograms and coherence-based maps. Furthermore, it was observed that the application of a threshold value to the coherence histogram enabled the classification of forested areas in the region."
For more information on this research see: Investigation of InSAR Coherence Data and Frequency Ratio for Analyzing Forest Fires: A Case Study of Yamanlar, Izmir. The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, 2025,XLVIII-M-6-2025():109-115. (The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences - http://www.isprs.org/publications/archives.aspx). The publisher for The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences is Copernicus Publications.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.5194/isprs-archives-XLVIII-M-6-2025-109-2025.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting G. Y. Cukurlu, Akdeniz University, Institute of Natural and Applied Sciences, Department of Space Science and Technologies, 07258 Konyaalti, Antalya, Turkiye. Additional authors for this research include N. Demir, P. Kolokousis, F. Aydin-Kandemir, E. Erlat.
Keywords for this news article include: Akdeniz University, Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, Science.

urn:contentItem:6GG8-M5R3-S00J-C2TN-00000-00Research from Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University in the Area of Physics Published (Optimized Wireless Sensor Network Architecture for AI-Based Wildfire Detection in Remote Areas)2025-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisPHYSICSResearch from Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University in the Area of Physics Published (Optimized Wireless Sensor Network Architecture for AI-Based Wildfire Detection in Remote Areas)


2025 AUG 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- Current study results on physics have been published. According to news reporting from Dammam, Saudi Arabia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Wildfires are complex natural disasters that significantly impact ecosystems and human communities. The early detection and prediction of forest fire risk are necessary for effective forest management and resource protection."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University: "This paper proposes an innovative early detection system based on a wireless sensor network (WSN) composed of interconnected Arduino nodes arranged in a hybrid circular/star topology. This configuration reduces the number of required nodes by 53-55% compared to conventional Mesh 2D topologies while enhancing data collection efficiency. Each node integrates temperature/humidity sensors and uses ZigBee communication for the real-time monitoring of wildfire risk conditions. This optimized topology ensures 41-81% lower latency and 50-60% fewer hops than conventional Mesh 2D topologies. The system also integrates artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms (multiclass logistic regression) to process sensor data and predict fire risk levels with 99.97% accuracy, enabling proactive wildfire mitigation. Simulations for a 300 m radius area show the non-dense hybrid topology is the most energy-efficient, outperforming dense and Mesh 2D topologies."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Additionally, the dense topology achieves the lowest packet loss rate (PLR), reducing losses by up to 80.4% compared to Mesh 2D. Adaptive routing, dynamic round-robin arbitration, vertical tier jumps, and GSM connectivity ensure reliable communication in remote areas, providing a cost-effective solution for wildfire mitigation and broader environmental monitoring."
For more information on this research see: Optimized Wireless Sensor Network Architecture for AI-Based Wildfire Detection in Remote Areas. Fire, 2025,8(7):245. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8070245.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Safiah Almarri, Department of Physics, College of Science & Humanities Jubail, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam 31961, Saudi Arabia. Additional authors for this research include Hur Al Safwan, Shahd Al Qisoom, Soufien Gdaim, Abdelkrim Zitouni.
Keywords for this news article include: Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam, Saudi Arabia, Asia, Network Architectures, Networks, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6GH1-8W13-RWPF-00B6-00000-00Flash drought fueled by dry weather, extreme heat now affecting over 1 million Mainers2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisFlash drought fueled by dry weather, extreme heat now affecting over 1 million MainersBy Gillian Graham Staff Writer

More than a third of Maine is now in moderate drought thanks in part to weeks of dry weather and extreme heat, according to new data released Thursday by the U.S. Drought Monitor, with much of the rest of the state facing conditions just shy of an official drought.

The flash drought conditions developed in a matter of weeks and are likely to spread and worsen through the end of the month, said Sarah Jamison, service hydrologist with the National Weather Service office in Gray.

More than 1 million people live in the drought area, which encompasses much of southern, central and Down East Maine. Another 43.6% of the state - including the western mountains, highlands and eastern interior - is experiencing abnormally dry conditions, one step below an official drought. Only the far northern reaches of Maine are still considered to have normal conditions.

"Every one of us has gotten used to these dry, hot spells when your lawn gets a little crispy and the lakes are a little low," Jamison said. "It's gone from, 'My garden needs more watering' to suddenly seeing water restrictions or more wildfires across the state."

As of Wednesday, there have been 508 wildfires in Maine this year - including more than 100 in August alone - said Terri Teller, a forest fire prevention specialist with the Maine Forest Service. The dry weather has exacerbated wildfire risks in much of the state.

Maine Forest Service rangers have responded to dozens of wildfires just this week and on Wednesday issued a warning on social media about the very high fire danger. Local fire wardens have stopped issuing burn permits, and officials are asking members of the public to be extremely cautious when burning any material.

In a moderate drought, wildfires and ground fires increase, honey production declines, hay and grain yields are lower than normal, and trees, landscaping and fish are stressed, according to the drought monitor.

People may be asked to voluntarily conserve water because reservoir and lake levels are below normal capacity.

Jamison said drought conditions are likely to worsen before they get better. There is no significant rainfall expected anytime soon, and Maine is expected to see lower humidity in the next week.

Conditions across Maine started to get a little dry earlier this summer but rapidly declined coming into August because there has been little or no rainfall for much of the state, Jamison said.

Most of Maine is now 3 to 5 inches of rainfall below normal, Jamison said.

Over the next week, some scattered showers may develop in parts of the state, but not the wetting rainfall - more than a quarter inch of widespread rain - that is needed to make a difference, Jamison said.

This story will be updated.

urn:contentItem:6GBT-82B3-RWC6-0323-00000-00Weekend air quality expected to be poor throughout Northland2025-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSWeekend air quality expected to be poor throughout NorthlandThe Pine Journal, Cloquet, Minn.

Jul. 18—ST. PAUL — Another weekend plagued by wildfire smoke is on tap, according to a report issued from the Minnesota Department of Health on Friday afternoon.

The department has issued an air quality alert that includes the entirety of the Northland, going into effect on Saturday at 1 p.m. and lasting until 9 a.m. on Monday.

According to a report from the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, there are still more than 200 wildfires burning in Saskatchewan, Manitoba and western Ontario. Surface smoke from those fires will drift south into northern Minnesota and eventually Wisconsin over the course of the day, then linger in the area on Sunday due to light winds before exiting north on Monday morning.

Areas including Koochiching, northern St. Louis, Lake and Cook counties have been classified in the purple, or "very unhealthy for everyone," category. A red, or "unhealthy for everyone," classification has been issued for an area that includes Duluth and surrounding areas as well as Carlton County.

People who are outside may experience irritated eyes, nose, and throat, coughing, chest tightness, or shortness of breath. Sensitive or more exposed individuals may experience more serious health effects, including worsening of existing heart or lung disease and respiratory and cardiovascular conditions, possibly leading to an asthma attack, heart attack, or stroke.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88C3-RWV2-G4T5-00000-00Lightning started the worst fire of the summer: Fasgar, in León, has been burning for 22 days2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisLightning started the worst fire of the summer: Fasgar, in León, has been burning for 22 days


In addition to causing the loss of four lives, and that is the worst of it, the wave of fires raging in Spain this summer is so immense that it seems impossible to single out one misfortune: 400,000 hectares burned, at least 170,000 hectares of reserves or natural parks? But even so, one name stands out: Fasgar, in El Bierzo (León), where the flames have been burning uninterruptedly since 5:24 p.m. on August 8, that is, for 22 days now.


Fasgar, with only 25 inhabitants, most of whom have not left their homes, is the epicenter of this disaster, but many municipalities in the area are holding their breath: Garaño, Molinaseca, Viñayo, Piedrasecha, Portilla de Luna, Sagüera de Luna, Vegapujín, Posada de Omaña, Lombillo de los Barrios, Torrecillo and Barrio de la Puente. Many villages in the region have been evicted two and three times.
It was not a pyromaniac or an arsonist, remember the neighbors of León affected by the worst forest fire or the longest lasting in Spain since there are records. That Friday 22 days ago the lightning of a dry storm started the flames, according to all hypotheses. It was, as José Manuel Roche, farmer and agrarian leader of Teruel, said recently in this website, an arson, although not intentional.
Dry storms are characterized by a great profusion of lightning and thunder, although it does not rain. Actually, it does rain, but the drops evaporate before they reach the ground because of the high temperatures and the dryness of the soil. Lightning and wind are a very dangerous cocktail and have caused fires in the past, but not as serious as this one. The tongue of fire is still out of control and exhibiting a virulence that makes it difficult to extinguish.
The Junta de Castilla y León admitted Thursday the "difficulties" faced by the authorities to stop the advance of the flames. Those responsible for the EU aerial resources displaced to León also recognize that they had never seen such voracity. The neighbors, who cannot stand it any longer, no longer trust even in a miracle. Many nights they have gone to bed, at dawn and exhausted, with the belief that the end was near, but....
But in the morning they have proven again and again that these were false hopes. The lack of rain and the heat are not the only allies of the fire. Wind is the third vertex of the triangle. The gales in the region have fanned outbreaks that seemed to be under control and have once again forced the evacuation of villages that thought they had returned to normal. The drop in night temperatures that slowed the flames was only a mirage.
The Fasgar fire, as it is already known, although there are dozens of municipalities affected, has two foci, in Igüeña and Colinas del Campo de Martín. Right now it is the most worrying red spot in Castilla y León, which is as much as to say in the whole of Spain because there are a dozen more active fires, but none as uncontrolled as this one. Thousands of hectares have already been devastated in the region of Omaña and in the lands of Bierzo.
The fire, which advances easily through a difficult orography in which the terrestrial means can do little, has almost totally burned the birch forest of Montrondo, a forest of great ecological interest and a natural jewel, which this generation and the next ones will never see again as it was. The general director of Civil Protection, Virginia Barcones, has admitted that this fire, "the most unfavorable in the whole country", is "very worrying".
Yes, the wave of fires is so immense that it seems impossible to highlight a misfortune, but some data can be given. Most of the fires, with the exception of Fasgar, are stabilized or controlled (not extinguished, although they are moving in the right direction). Since August 8, 35,691 people have been evacuated and 53 suspected arsonists have been arrested. Against the worst of them all, however, there is nothing to be done. It was lightning.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G1B3-RS1P-J4NX-00000-00From catastrophe to opportunity: forestry experts see feasibility of recovering a good part of the 400,000 hectares burned2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisFrom catastrophe to opportunity: forestry experts see feasibility of recovering a good part of the 400,000 hectares burned


This Friday the Minister of Presidency of Extremadura, Abel Bautista, announced that the de-escalation of the Jarilla fire that has devastated around 17,000 hectares. Gradually, the evicted residents will be able to return to their homes, once the conditions to control the fire have become more favorable. Spain has spent most of August with its heart in its hands because of the different outbreaks that have ravaged the peninsula. On Monday, 2025 became the year with the largest area razed in the state in the entire historical series of Copernicus, which began in 2006. In the midst of this blazing storm, a glimmer of hope is beginning to emerge. And in this context, a question arises: what will happen when everything is over? How do we take care of the scorched earth?


Experts have tried to answer this question. And like all other scientific questions, there is no simple, unambiguous answer to this one either. "One of the first things you really do is wait; wait to see how the land reacts and see how it evolves," Jorge Aguado, a technician with WWFSpain's Forestry program, explains to Público. In some cases, human intervention is not necessary because the reaction of the environment may be favorable to their recovery.
What about current cases? According to Miguel Ángel Soto, biologist and head of the Greenpeace Forests campaign, "an important part of what is burning are Mediterranean-type species, shrubs that are going to resprout from stumps". Soto stresses that this regeneration is due to the fact that "fire is part of the ecosystem". That is, although most fires are caused by humans, as indicated to this medium WWF sources, there is a percentage associated with lightning storms.
Related to this topicThe wave of fires ravaging Spain in summer reveals a social, territorial and ecological crisis
Adhik Arrilucea

Miguel Angel Soto (Greenpeace): "Many scrublands that are burning now will regenerate next spring."
"Fire is a natural part of the Mediterranean climate," Cristina Santín, a researcher at the Joint Institute for Biodiversity Research (IMIB), part of the CSIC, tells this newspaper. "We have enough precipitation from winter to spring for vegetation to grow, while the summer season is sufficiently dry and hot for this vegetation to be susceptible to burning." For this reason, the evolution of some plants has been determined by their interaction with flames. "The cork oak has a bark that insulates the tree from fire. In addition, the seeds of some pine species are generated precisely once the pine cone has dried and the fire has passed," exemplifies Soto. "Many thickets that are burning now are going to regenerate next spring, they are going to be green," he emphasizes.
Not all the bush is oregano (or forest).
However, this reality does not apply to 100% of the burned area. Aguado points out that there will be areas where it will be necessary to act, such as the juniper groves. "The juniper does not resprout and is a species that takes hundreds of years to develop an arboreal habit, so we have to intervene there. In general, the way to act will depend on each territory, since the species are not the same, nor are the environmental conditions in all parts of the peninsula. The way to proceed must therefore take into account the particularities of each scenario in its full magnitude.
Antonio Aretxabala, geologist: "We must know whether we want forest, i.e. more industrial exploitation, or forest".
Geologist and science popularizer Antonio Aretxabala adds another fundamental nuance to understand what happens after a forest fire. "You have to differentiate between forest and forest," he tells Público. "The forest has an extractive connotation, it is an industrial monoculture, for example, to use the wood. So, the forest is burned". On the other hand, "the forest has a series of dynamics very rich in biodiversity, in exchange between the atmosphere, the bark, living beings and water, which make it very resistant to fire", he clarifies. With this in mind, in order to know what we can do after a forest fire, "we must know whether we want forest, that is, more industrial exploitation, or forest," the scientist points out.
Aguado also emphasizes that "not everything that is forest is forest". And he remarks, in relation to what we want, that "there is a tremendous opportunity" in restoration work. "We have the opportunity to give the local population enough tools to be able to live again from the forest and have a landscape in the form of a mosaic, more resilient to forest fires".
Related to this topicWhy do fires rage in Zamora, León and Ourense? The factors that cause the 'fire triangle'.
María Martínez Collado
An obsession with reforestation?
In this sense, Soto recalls that "Spain is the third European country in terms of forest area. Although we have a feeling that it is brown and yellow, we are a green country". With this in mind, he suggests that "we are not interested in everything [burned] becoming forest, so we are interested in mosaic landscapes, in recovering agricultural or non-forested areas". The biologist agrees with the idea of the other experts: "We have to restore landscapes, not necessarily replant trees.
WWF's annual report on forest fires in 2024 pointed out that "restoration has traditionally been understood as reforestation". The organization thus criticized that "mere tree planting" is insufficient to restore healthy and diverse ecosystems that can better adapt to mega-fires or the climate crisis.
Related to this topicSpain is experiencing an environmental catastrophe never seen before: mega-fires are already exceeding the capacity for extinction
Adhik Arrilucea

Soto also questions "the obsession with planting trees". Instead, he advocates analyzing "what kind of landscapes we need for summers like 2025, which may be normal summers". The head of Greenpeace's forests campaign warns that large waves of fires like those that have ravaged Spain this month may become more frequent. Faced with the extraordinary sensation that the current catastrophe has given us, "maybe we have to get used to the fact that this is the normal summer", considers the biologist.
Prevention in the face of changes in the uses of the landscape
The transformation in the uses that humans have made of the landscape is implicated in the new behavior of forest fires, whose size is increasing. Current trends indicate that the number of outbreaks is decreasing, but their extent is increasing. Therefore, the frequency of the so-called Large Forest Fires (LFF), those exceeding 500 hectares, is increasing. The dimensions of the fires can be so large that they generate their own climatology, becoming gigantic masses of fire, totally unpredictable and exceeding the capacity of extinction.
Related to this topicGreenpeace and WWF reject that tougher penalties as proposed by the PP will curb fires
Raúl Bocanegra / Adhik Arrilucea

Specifically, changes in the uses of the landscape that have led to this new kind of fires have to do with rural depopulation. This abandonment means a decline "of extensive agriculture and livestock, leaving an accumulation of continuous forest masses," says Monica Colmena, a technician in WWF's Forestry program, in an interview with this newspaper. This means that the landscape has fewer and fewer obstacles to the advance of flames, making it more flammable.
From Greenpeace, Miguel Ángel Soto adds that this is not a recent phenomenon. "There has been a migration from the countryside to the cities in Spain since the 1960s," he says. Transformations in the way society is organized, more based on the industrial and tertiary sector, result in transformations on the ecosystems themselves and the events that take place in them. Moreover, when it comes to fires, these changes in the landscape are aggravated by the effects of the climate crisis, with increasingly higher temperatures and more frequent and longer-lasting heat waves.
With this in mind, some of the most frequently mentioned prevention measures among members of the scientific community have to do with encouraging grazing or designing mosaic landscapes. "We need to activate a forestry sector that acts as a tractor so that towns have people who live off local resources, and that those resources are managed," defends Soto. Although it is said that "fires are extinguished in winter," all the tools available to carry out effective policies now find a new window of opportunity open.

urn:contentItem:6GPM-X9B3-S1KJ-22N1-00000-00China: Guan County, Shandong Province continues to improve grassroots emergency rescue capabilities2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisChina: Guan County, Shandong Province continues to improve grassroots emergency rescue capabilities

Key Highlights:

* Guan County, Shandong Province, has developed a new '1+19+N' model for emergency rescue teams, enhancing grassroots emergency rescue capabilities.

* The County Emergency Management Bureau established 5 research working groups to identify shortcomings and weaknesses in emergency plans and team establishment.

* 13 relevant systems were established and improved to strengthen command management, improve preferential treatment and security policies, and enhance the sense of professional honor among emergency rescue team members.

Original Press Release:

Sept. 9 -- Ministry of Emergency Management of the People's Republic of China issued the following news release:

In recent years, Guan County, Shandong Province has focused on building a large-scale security and emergency work pattern, innovatively created a new model of "1+19+N" emergency rescue team, and established a complete emergency rescue system with unified command at the county level, linkage between counties and townships, mutual cooperation among departments, and active participation of enterprises, to promote the continuous improvement of grassroots emergency rescue capabilities.

Establish and improve institutional mechanisms. The County Emergency Management Bureau established five research working groups and hired experts in the field of emergency response. By reviewing materials and conducting on-site inspections, they comprehensively understood the status of emergency plan compilation, emergency drills, team establishment, and material reserves in various departments, towns, and streets, focusing on identifying shortcomings and weaknesses to fill gaps in the construction of grassroots emergency rescue teams. Based on the research results, the "Guan County Implementation Plan for Promoting Grassroots Emergency Rescue Capacity Building" was formulated to clarify construction goals, refine construction steps, and determine the division of tasks among relevant county departments and support measures in terms of finance, emergency equipment, and occupational security. 13 related systems, including the "Guan County Emergency Rescue Team Command and Dispatch System" and the "Guan County Emergency Rescue Team Daily Management System," were established and improved to strengthen command and management, improve preferential treatment and security policies, and enhance the sense of professional honor among members of the emergency rescue team.

Improve the rescue team system. Comprehensively sort out the personnel strength of the County Emergency Management Bureau, Fire Rescue Brigade, Blue Sky Rescue Center and various towns and streets, integrate the existing team equipment, and build a county-level emergency rescue brigade, 19 township emergency rescue squadrons, and N joint mutual aid emergency rescue teams. At the county level, with the firefighters recruited by the County Emergency Management Bureau and retired teams as the team, the county-level emergency rescue brigade was formed by absorbing relevant personnel from the County Blue Sky Rescue Center, totaling 43 people, to strengthen the interconnection with the fire rescue team and improve the efficiency of large-scale emergency and rescue. At the town and street level, each town and street and county economic development zone uses grassroots militia as the team, absorbs professional personnel from towns and streets and some key enterprises, integrates the existing fire trucks, equipment and equipment of towns and streets, and forms 19 township-level emergency rescue squadrons, totaling 205 people, establishes and improves team rules and regulations to ensure self-rescue in small disasters and reinforcement in large disasters. At the enterprise level, the county economic development zones and town and street industrial clusters are divided into N grid emergency points. 5-10 adjacent enterprises in each grid form a joint mutual assistance emergency rescue team to establish an initial rescue and mutual rescue mechanism of enterprise self-rescue, neighboring mutual rescue, and emergency point first aid.

Strengthening supplies and equipment development. To enhance material reserves, the county government coordinated office space for the County Emergency Rescue Brigade, establishing functional facilities such as offices, conference rooms, equipment storage, and a physical training room. The County Emergency Management Bureau purchased and allocated emergency rescue equipment, established five equipment storage facilities, and stocked over 1,500 pieces of various equipment, creating a coordinated support mechanism combining peacetime and emergency response. The County implemented a support system combining government leadership, corporate participation, and social donations, formulated the "Measures for the Management of Sharing Social Rescue Equipment," and established a system for equipment performance certification and regular maintenance.

Continue to carry out education and training. Thoroughly study General Secretary Xi Jinping's important expositions on work safety, disaster prevention, mitigation, and relief, and learn relevant laws, regulations, and policy documents on emergency management, so as to ensure that the concept of "people first, life first" takes root in people's minds. Recruit professional rescue personnel to organize and conduct professional rescue knowledge and skills training, and implement quasi-military management. Organize special practical training every quarter, focusing on forest fire prevention and rescue training in the spring, highlighting water rescue and flood prevention and emergency drills in the summer, focusing on hazardous chemical leaks and traffic accident handling in the autumn, and strengthening ice and snow disaster rescue in the winter, so as to achieve dynamic synchronization between capacity building and the laws of disaster occurrence. Promote scientific and technological empowerment, deepen the application of new technologies such as water rescue robots, and enhance disaster reconnaissance and personnel search and rescue capabilities.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VP93-RSMG-X2SN-00000-00Evelyn, rescuer who helped in the pipe explosion in Iztapalapa, narrates her experience as a volunteer: "It hurts day by day".2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisEvelyn, rescuer who helped in the pipe explosion in Iztapalapa, narrates her experience as a volunteer: "It hurts day by day".

For Evelyn Gonzalez, the afternoon of Tuesday, September 10, seemed like any other. After finishing her morning workday, she was about to go to her classes at the School of Chemical Engineering and Extractive Industries (ESIQIE) of the National Polytechnic Institute (IPN), but the tragic news of the explosion of a gas pipeline on the Concordia Bridge in Iztapalapa, forced her to abruptly change her itinerary.For the past two years, the young woman, originally from Veracruz, has been a member of the Agrupamiento Deportivo Militarizado Condor, an organization that trains volunteers to handle emergencies and other civil protection activities. In an interview with MILENIO, she spoke about her experience at the scene of the incident and shared some recommendations for citizens to be better prepared for these cases. "Many people wanted to help" after the explosion "Are you going to activate?"

was the message Evelyn sent to a colleague from the group, who lives near her house, when she heard about the incident in Iztapalapa. After receiving an affirmative response, the 26-year-old grabbed her protective gear and the two traveled to 'ground zero' on a motorcycle and upon arriving at the incident site, Evelyn and her colleague were met with what she called "chaos". The immediate effects of the explosion, the uncertainty about its dimensions and the desire of dozens of citizens to support the emergency services turned the scene into a maelstrom.Evelyn's initial involvement in the explosion consisted of providing pre-hospital care to a firefighter who was on the front line of the firefighting effort. Moments later, she focused on orienting the surrounding population to prevent any risk situation.During the interview, Evelyn emphasized that, although the intention of the citizens to get involved in these cases is appreciated, this can sometimes generate new threats, both for the victims of a contingency and for those interested in participating. "Many people wanted to help, there were too many hands. But trying to help civilians is also a risk for them and for the emergency in general," said the young woman, who is studying Industrial Chemical Engineering, noting, for example, that some people in the area of the Concordia Bridge tried to throw water on those who had suffered burns from the explosion. Civil Protection authorities have specified that, when faced with an injury of this nature, the application of water or ice on wounds should be avoided.An explanation shared by staff at Woman's Hospital of Texas warns that, in these scenarios, ice decreases blood flow to the affected area, which can delay the healing process. On the other hand, cold water can further damage the tissue and increase the risk of infection. In this sense, he considered that the preparation of Mexican citizens for emergency care is practically nil, since on many occasions it is a subject that is not followed up. She regretted, for example, that earthquake drills are often not taken seriously and that other scenarios, such as floods or fires, are rarely taken into account.What motivated Evelyn to become a volunteer?Evelyn is the first member of her family to get involved in rescue work. Being a "charitable soul" and having a "chicken heart", as she described herself, her altruistic spirit found the necessary motivation to train at a time when her father was in a delicate health condition.Her first approach to this field was through Auri Anaid Martinez, who besides being a professor of Industrial Legislation at ESIQIE, is a commander of the Condor Military Sports Group. "She made us [several of her students] the cordial invitation to join the group. At that moment in my life I wanted to know how to take better care of my dad, in an efficient but also human way, without putting myself or the people around me at risk. "It hurts day by day": the life of volunteers outside of emergenciesIn the conversation with MILENIO, Evelyn González emphasized that the members of the Agrupamiento Cóndor, being volunteers, have a life apart from the activities they carry out in the area of civil protection.Although their work as rescuers is restricted to the first hours of the contingency, in the following days they assume the responsibility of taking care of themselves and accompanying each other. "After such shocking missions we try to have a meeting in which everyone expresses their feelings, because it is hard to see the situation and for many it is shocking. Despite the risks and the emotional impact that this work can bring, Evelyn said that she sees herself participating as a volunteer for a long time, because it is something that "fills the soul" and has left her with valuable lessons. The main learning is empathy with the victims, being that hand that comforts and gives hope, relieves too much. You also have to give psychological first aid and have an efficient first approach. I have also learned to take care of myself and to value life. The human being is very fragile and then we do not realize that".besides carrying out rescue actions after the explosion of the pipe in Iztapalapa, Evelyn collaborated in the attention to emergencies such as Hurricane John in Acapulco (Guerrero), floods in the Magdalena Contreras district (Mexico City), the fire in a plastics factory in Ecatepec (State of Mexico) and the forest fire in Atltzayanca (Tlaxcala).BM.

urn:contentItem:6GK0-YH03-S169-P3V4-00000-00Toronto's had a summer of extreme heat. In 2050, it might be par for the course, climatologist says2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisTORONTO NEWS & CANADA NEWSToronto's had a summer of extreme heat. In 2050, it might be par for the course, climatologist says

This summer has been one of the hottest on record in Toronto, with six heat waves recorded already, but climatologists have a message for people who've felt like the dog days are getting hotter and longer: get used to it.

Conservative forecasting models suggest the extreme heat of this summer will be the average in 2025, says Environment Canada climatologist David Phillips.

The summer of 2025, which still has four weeks to go, has already had double the annual average of days over 32 degrees Celsius, according to Environment Canada. In 2000, temperatures were that high on average four days a year.

That's gone up up to seven over the past five years. 

"This summer, we've had 14 of those suckers," said Phillips. In 25 years, models suggest an average of 15 to 16 days above 32 C.

"It's almost like a dress rehearsal, a preview, a glimpse of what summers are going to be like in 2050," he said. "Nature's giving us a head's up."

WATCH | Recent heat wave breaks Canadian records: 

Lauren Hazlewood grew up in the Caribbean, but she says the heat in Toronto has been hitting her hard this summer.

"I feel like even it's become a bit unbearable for me, especially as a commuter," she told CBC Toronto this week. "Being on the bus, on the streetcar, it's very warm. I usually try to bike to work and I've kind of given up on that."

Sanaz Ghasemi, who lives in a condo downtown, says she normally loves hot and humid weather, but it's been weighing on her this year.

"It's just like warning signs of the kind of direction we're heading. It's a little bit scary," she said. 

Today's extremes, tomorrow's norms

But hotter nights could be even more alarming, Phillips said.

"Major cities just don't cool off. There's too much asphalt and building materials and concrete," he said.

In 2000, there were an average of 12 nights each year in Toronto above 20 C. So far this year, there have been 24 that have hit that temperature. Models suggest an average of 23 nights like that in the city in 2025, Phillips said.

And those are just the expected averages. Phillips says extremes 25 years from now will look much worse.

"Imagine a whole month or more of temperatures that are getting up to 33 degrees [Celsius] at least," he said. "And of course with the heat and the dryness, it brings on more fires. And so we're adding smoke into that."

Canada has already had its three worst forest fire seasons on record all in the last three years, he says.

Droughts caused by extreme heat can also make the impacts of other extreme weather more severe, says CBC meteorologist Colette Kennedy.

"We could have too much rain at once, [so] that we can't absorb it," she said. That could mean worse flooding in the city.

Phillips says it's crucial cities like Toronto continue to take concrete actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to curtail the effects of climate change, while also making sure that infrastructure can handle more extreme summers.

Extreme heat can warp rail tracks, slowing trains, for instance, or melt asphalt on roads, he says.

"When we rebuild or build newer infrastructure, we better wake up to the fact that our climate has changed," Phillips said.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

Weyerhaeuser Company has consistently demonstrated its commitment to sustainable forestry and community development through strategic investments and philanthropic efforts. Recently, Weyerhaeuser made headlines with its land donation for the Row River wildfire substation, exemplifying its leadership in wildfire protection and emergency services partnerships. This initiative underscores Weyerhaeuser's dedication to wildfire mitigation and response infrastructure, crucial in safeguarding forests and nearby communities.

In West Virginia, Weyerhaeuser's investment strategy is robust, epitomized by a $1 million community investment in Buckhannon. This investment is set to bolster rural economic development and enhance Weyerhaeuser's community grants and support efforts. Highlighting its philanthropic endeavors, Weyerhaeuser's charitable giving focuses on corporate social responsibility, revered by the Buckhannon community for fostering sustainable forestry.

Through such initiatives, including timberland and forestland donations, Weyerhaeuser maintains a steadfast commitment to land stewardship, enhancing community resilience, and ensuring a sustainable future for generations. Weyerhaeuser's overarching goal remains clear: elevating community development while ensuring the sustainability of critical ecosystems.

Press Release article 2 of 12, Source: Company Website, 334 words

October 30: Weyerhaeuser Provides Update on Timberlands Portfolio Optimization Actions

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced updates on recent actions to enhance portfolio quality and value through a series of strategic and capital-efficient timberland transactions. In the third quarter, the company completed two high-quality acquisitions totaling $459 million, including its previously announced transaction for timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia. Additionally, in the third quarter Weyerhaeuser advanced three divestiture packages of non-core timberlands - two of which were closed or under contract in early October, totaling $410 million of expected cash proceeds by year end. The company anticipates the third divestiture to close in early 2026, with total proceeds from all divestitures expected to exceed the cash outlay required for its recently completed acquisitions.

"These transactions represent strategic opportunities to recycle capital in a tax-efficient manner to further optimize and improve our timberlands portfolio," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our timber holdings and have remained disciplined and nimble in our approach to growing the quality and value of our timberlands. Through this process, we've achieved the multi-year growth target we announced in September 2021 - and by early 2026, we will have offset a significant portion of our acquisitions with divestitures of non-core acreage. Over a similar period, we've also returned a substantial amount of cash back to shareholders through dividends and share repurchase and announced a compelling engineered wood products growth opportunity - all while maintaining a strong balance sheet. Looking forward, we will continue to evaluate capital-efficient opportunities that enhance the return profile of our timberlands, while also balancing other levers across our capital allocation framework to drive superior long-term value for our shareholders."

Summary of Acquisitions

Unique, off-market transactions featuring high-quality and strategically located acreage with portfolio-leading timber and financial attributes in their respective regions.

Acquired at a combined timber-only Adjusted EBITDA multiple of 21x1.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.
