MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&A)

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

For Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) related to the year ended December 31, 2022, refer to this same section in our 2023 annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on February 16, 2024.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-9743-RT9P-40VW-00000-00Climate crisis has set the stage for 22% more intense forest fires in Europe2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisClimate crisis has set the stage for 22% more intense forest fires in Europe


More than a million hectares have already burned in Europe this year. While it is undeniable that the dry weather and successive heatwaves on the continent have contributed to the record, a new attribution study shows that the climate crisis also set the stage months earlier, making the fires 22% more intense.


The estimate comes from the WWA (World Weather Attribution), a panel of scientists that investigates the responsibility of the climate crisis in extreme events. The rapid study, which has yet to be peer-reviewed but works with established climate parameters and models, analyzed data from Turkey, Greece and Cyprus, which since June have been fighting forest fires at temperatures reaching 45°C.
"It seems clear that something similar has happened in Spain and Portugal, which recorded the highest levels of destruction until last week," says Friederike Otto, Professor of Climate Science and Environmental Policy at Imperial College, the institution leading the WWA studies.
"Today, with a warming of 1.3°C [of the planet, compared to pre-industrial levels], we are registering new extremes in the behavior of forest fires, which are pushing firefighters to the limit. The problem is that we are heading for a warming of up to 3°C this century if nothing is done," says Theodore Keeping, a researcher at the London institution, projecting a situation without a transition to clean energy.
Together with experts from Turkey and Greece, Keeping observed that the scenario for the current burning season began to form months ago: total winter precipitation in the region has decreased by around 14% compared to that recorded in the pre-industrial era, which leads to drier conditions in summer and a greater degree of flammability.
The group then analyzed how the intense, dry heat prepared the plants to burn just before the fires started thanks to a metric that reflects how "thirsty" the air is, in the language of the study. It found that a week of high evaporation conditions is now around 13 times more likely and 18% more intense.
A similar situation of heat, dryness and strong winds, according to the climate models applied, would have been a rare event before the adoption of fossil fuels, likely to occur every 100 years. With global warming, the chance of repetition drops to 20 years in statistical terms.
All in all, conditions conducive to fires have become 10 times more likely and 22% more intense due to climate change.
"In Turkey, the fires broke out very early, in the middle of June. In general, this is only expected in mid-July. When the vegetation is dry and the winds are strong, a single ignition, regardless of its origin, from human activity or not, can quickly turn into a forest fire that is difficult to control," says Bikem Ekberzade, from Istanbul Technical University.
"Here in Greece, we are facing almost three consecutive years of above-normal monthly temperatures. This makes extreme forest fires almost inevitable," says Apostolos Voulgarakis, a professor at the University of Crete and director of the department dedicated to the subject at Imperial College.
In addition to local data, the attribution study analyzed a variable developed in Canada to measure the difficulty of putting out a fire from the moment it is ignited. The DSR (Daily Severity Rating) combines temperature, humidity, wind speed and rainfall to determine the intensity of the fire.
"It is this variable that tells us that the conditions that caused such devastation are 10 times more likely and 22% more intense due to climate change," explains Keeping, the Imperial College researcher.
More than 50,000 people were evacuated in Turkey, which also recorded 17 deaths in June and July. 624 forest fires have been identified, devastating more than 60,000 hectares.
In Greece, 32,000 people had to be evacuated, including 5,000 tourists in Crete. The economic damage is still being counted.
In Cyprus, 1% of the island burned, killing two people and forcing the evacuation of the population in 14 towns.
This is the balance covered by the study. The fires are still raging, with one death in Greece now in August, on what was classified as the worst day of the summer in the country so far.

urn:contentItem:6GNK-M8R3-RRV7-C0C2-00000-00Spain/Portugal: Climate change fuelled wildfires of 'unprecedented intensity' in Spain and Portugal, experts say2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSSpain/Portugal: Climate change fuelled wildfires of 'unprecedented intensity' in Spain and Portugal, experts say

Climate change made weather that fuelled Portugal and Spain's deadly wildfires this summer around 40 times more likely, new research has found.

Blazes in the Iberian Peninsula broke out at the end of July. Fuelled by temperatures above 40\xB0C and strong winds, the flames spread extremely rapidly. The area burned by these wildfires has now broken records across Spain and Portugal.

A new super rapid scientific analysis by World Weather Attribution (WWA) has found that these hot, dry and windy conditions were made more likely and more intense by human-caused climate change.

Dr Clair Barnes, researcher for the Centre for Environmental Policy at Imperial College London, warns that the astonishing size of these fires is a sign of what is to come with hotter, drier, more flammable conditions becoming more severe with climate change.

It is giving rise to fires of unprecedented intensity".

With every fraction of a degree of warming, extreme, long-lasting heatwaves will continue to intensify, increasing the chance of huge wildfires like the ones that burned vast areas of the Iberian Peninsula, she says.

Climate change made fire-prone conditions more intense

Scientists found climate change intensified the weather that enabled the explosive spread of the fires, including Spain's hottest consecutive ten days on record.

The hot, dry and windy conditions that fuelled the fires in Spain and Portugal are now around 40 times more frequent and around 30 per cent more intense than they would be in a world without climate change.

Before climate change, similar extreme spells of hot, dry and windy conditions would have been incredibly rare and expected once every 500 years. Today, with 1.3\xB0C of warming, they are expected once every 15 years.

Scientists also looked at the heatwave, finding that in a world without climate change, similar events would be expected less than every 2,500 years. With current warming, they are expected once every 13 years.

The results of the analysis back up a similar study recently released by WWA which found that climate change also intensified weather that fuelled deadly wildfires in T\xFCrkiye, Greece and Cyprus.

Europe's firefighters are under pressure

Experts say the study also highlights the strain on firefighters in Europe. Weather conditions have sparked large, unpredictable wildfires across the south of the continent, stretching the EU's resources.

Firefighters are increasingly working in chaotic and unpredictable conditions, tackling fires that behave in ways they've never seen before, says Centre for Environmental Policy researcher, Theodore Keeping.

As fires raged on 13 August, Spain made its first-ever request for international firefighting reinforcements to the European Civil Protection Mechanism. Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said it was likely the largest such request ever facilitated by the EU.

Climate change is fuelling more extreme wildfires, but adaptation isn't keeping pace. We need to see a shift in thinking and a greater focus on prevention," Keeping adds.

The scale of the fires across the Iberian Peninsula has put incredible pressure on resources.

More than 380,000 hectares of land have burned in Spain since the start of 2025 - almost five times the yearly average. In Portugal, more than 260,000 hectares have been lost. That is close to 3 per cent of the country's land mass and three times the average area burned by wildfires in a year.

The total area lost to wildfires across the two countries so far this year is roughly four times the size of Greater London. Together, fires in Spain and Portugal make up around two-thirds of Europe's total burned area for 2025, which, in August, passed one million hectares for the first time since records began in 2006, according to the European Forest Fire Information System.

Spain is being 'hit hard' by climate change

At least eight people have been killed by the blazes, and tens of thousands have been forced to evacuate. Smoke led to dangerous air quality in Spain and Portugal and has travelled as far as France, the UK and Scandinavia.

Friederike Otto, a climate science Professor at the Centre for Environmental Policy, says Spain is being hit hard by climate change.

These enormous fires follow the devastating floods in Valencia and another summer of relentless heat above 40\xB0C, she says.

Extreme weather is becoming more frequent, but deaths and damages are preventable. Every level of government must work together to adapt to climate change. For wildfires, there's an urgent need to control vegetation in rural areas, particularly land that has been abandoned by farmers and shepherds.

Public opinion in Spain has focused on the decline of rural activities, resulting in the growth of vegetation that has fuelled fires. Rural depopulation and an ageing population across parts of both Spain and Portugal have left forest land unmanaged. Fewer people and less traditional grazing have seen natural vegetation control sharply decline, leaving a lot of fuel for fires.

But, Professor Otto adds, ultimately, the world needs to stop burning fossil fuels.

The wildfires in Europe show that 1.3\xB0C of warming today is already incredibly dangerous. Without a faster shift away from fossil fuels, we could hit 3\xB0C this century. Wildfires at this level would be catastrophic.

Source: Euronews

urn:contentItem:6GF7-4V53-RSCF-40P6-00000-00A look at the hundreds of wildfires burning across the U.S. and Canada2025-08-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS, NATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & CANADA NEWSA look at the hundreds of wildfires burning across the U.S. and CanadaCaitlin Keith

Noah Berger

Smoke from the Gifford Fire fills the sky as the sun sets over Los Padres National Forest, Calif., on Monday, Aug. 4, 2025.

1

As dry, hot weather continues in fire-prone areas, there are hundreds of wildfires currently burning across the U.S. and Canada.

Some of these wildfires continue to grow to massive sizes as firefighting crews work to contain them.

Here is a look at how many fires are burning in both the U.S. and Canada.

A look at U.S. wildfires by the numbers

Noah Berger

California Wildfires

California Wildfires

1

According to the National Interagency Fire Center, there has been a total of 42,162 wildfires in the U.S. so far this year and over 3.4 million acres have been burned.

There were eight new fires reported across the country on Wednesday, as crews work to manage 42 uncontained large fires covering 576,316 acres.

A large fire is defined as "any wildland fire in timber 100 acres or greater, and 300 acres or greater in grasslands/rangelands, or has an Incident Management Team assigned to it," according to the Northwest Interagency Coordination Center.

There are currently 10 incident management teams, 283 crews, 784 engines and 105 helicopters working to manage the wildfires burning in the U.S.

National Fire News: 08/06. More than 42,000 wildfires have burned over 3.4 million acres across the country this year. 10 incident management teams, 283 crews, 784 engines, & 105 helicopters, are working hard to manage 42 uncontained large fires, with 8 new large fires reported. pic.twitter.com/B1MhduagBb

— National Interagency Fire Center (@NIFC_Fire)

August 6, 2025

According to the National Interagency Fire Center, large fires are currently burning in 10 U.S. states:

Colorado: nine

California: six

Idaho: six

Washington: five

Alaska: four

Arizona: four

Nevada: four

Utah: two

New Mexico: one

Montana: one

Mark Tarello, a meteorologist for Fox 40, posted a map of all the active wildfires in the U.S. and Canada on X.

A look at all the active wildfires today across the United States and Canada. #Wildfires pic.twitter.com/fLTsx3TQ1G

— Mark Tarello (@mark_tarello)

August 6, 2025

A look at the biggest fires burning in the U.S. right now

Abraham Freebairn

Grand Canyon Fire

Grand Canyon Fire

1

The biggest fire currently burning in the U.S. is the Dragon Bravo Fire in northern Arizona, which has burned over 126,882 acres and is considered a "megafire" since it's grown over 100,000 acres, per the National Interagency Fire Center.

USA Today shared a video on X of a pyrocumulus cloud, also known as a fire cloud, that was produced by the Dragon Bravo Fire.

Timelapse footage of the Grand Canyon captured a massive pyrocumulus cloud produced by the Dragon Bravo Fire, which is burning along the North Rim. pic.twitter.com/cyHMFDZwTn

— USA TODAY (@USATODAY)

August 1, 2025

The Dragon Bravo Fire started on July 4, and on Tuesday, it was 13% contained, according to The New York Times. The fire is burning along the Grand Canyon, and last month it destroyed the historic Grand Canyon Lodge and dozens of other structures at the canyon's North Rim.

Sean Parker, a professional photographer, shared a timelapse image he took of the Dragon Bravo Fire burning at the Grand Canyon.

A haunting beauty. The Dragon Bravo Fire burning through the Grand Canyon as stars and meteors pass silently overhead. It's hard to watch a place you love endure this, so I turned my lens to the sky and let it speak.#GrandCanyon #Astrophotography #Timelapse #DragonBravoFire pic.twitter.com/Tqn95blUHt

— Sean Parker (@seanparkerphoto)

August 2, 2025

Another large fire is the Gifford Fire, which is burning in central California and has burned 83,933 acres since it started last Friday, according to the National Interagency Fire Center.

So far, the Gifford Fire has been 9% contained and currently threatens over 800 structures. NBC News reported that three people have been injured by the fire burning through Los Padres National Forest.

On X, AccuWeather posted a video of the Gifford Fire captured by a California couple driving through the area.

A California couple captured their terrifying drive through the Gifford Fire as it broke out over the weekend.

The Gifford Fire has burned more than 65,000 acres in Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo counties. pic.twitter.com/y5xh6WeeuH

— AccuWeather (@accuweather)

August 5, 2025

The Monroe Fire, burning in Sevier County in central Utah, has burned 63,653 acres, according to the National Interagency Fire Center. The Monroe Fire is 15% contained.

How many fires are currently burning in Canada?

Yuki Iwamura

Air Quality Canadian Wildfires

Air Quality Canadian Wildfires

1

According to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, there have been six new fires reported on Wednesday as 752 active fires burn across the country.

So far this year, Canada has had 4,132 fires that have burned a total of 6.8 million acres.

Here's a look at where the most fires are burning in Canada, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre:

Manitoba: 165

British Columbia: 127

Northwest Territories: 111

Yukon: 100

Saskatchewan: 81

Ontario: 74

Alberta: 64

Air quality concerns in the Midwest and Northeast

Smoke drifting south from Canadian wildfires is continuing to cause air quality concerns and hazy skies in multiple places across the American Midwest and Northeast.

According to CBS News, air quality alerts were in effect on Wednesday morning in parts of 10 states: Delaware, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont, New York, Michigan, Illinois, Wisconsin and Minnesota.

There are also air quality concerns from fires burning in the Western U.S., with alerts in Colorado and Southern California on Wednesday, per Axios.

Certain groups, such as those with cardiovascular or respiratory disease, pregnant women, outdoor workers, older adults and children under 18, are more at risk to issues from the smoke in the air.

urn:contentItem:6GT6-TFX3-RRVJ-C02H-00000-00Spain deploys 500 more troops to battle wildfires amid heat wave2025-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. A8Spain deploys 500 more troops to battle wildfires amid heat waveBARRY HATTON Associated PressCamas

Lalo R. Villar/Associated Press

Firefighters battle a wildfire in Veiga das Meas, northwestern Spain, Saturday.

LISBON, Portugal - Spain is deploying a further 500 soldiers to battle wildfires that have torn through parched woodland during a prolonged spell of scorching weather, Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez said Sunday.


The decision to add to the more than 1,400 troops already on wildfire duty came as authorities struggled to contain forest blazes, especially in the northwestern Galicia region, and awaited the arrival of promised aircraft reinforcements from other European countries.
Firefighters are tackling 12 major wildfires in Galicia, all of them near the city of Ourense, the head of the Galician regional government Alfonso Rueda told a press conference with Sánchez.
"Homes are still under threat so we have lockdowns in place and are carrying out evacuations," Rueda said. Galicia has been battling the spreading flames for more than a week.
Temperatures in Spain could reach 113 degrees in some areas on Sunday, the Spanish national weather agency AEMET said. On Saturday, the maximum temperature was 112.46 degrees in the southern city of Cordoba, it said.
"This Sunday, when extraordinarily high temperatures are expected, the danger of wildfires is extreme in most of the country," AEMET said on the social platform X.
The fires in Spain this year have burned 390,000 acres, according to the European Union's European Forest Fire Information System.
That is an area roughly as big as metropolitan London.
Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service. Scientists say that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness in parts of Europe, making the region more vulnerable to wildfires.
Spain awaits firefighters, more planes
Spain was expecting the arrival of two Dutch water-dumping planes that were to join aircraft from France and Italy already helping Spanish authorities under a European cooperation agreement.
Firefighters from other countries are also expected to arrive in the region in coming days, Spain's Civil Protection Agency chief Virginia Barcones told public broadcaster RTVE.
National rail operator Renfe said it suspended Madrid-Galicia high-speed train services scheduled for Sunday due to the fires.
Galician authorities advised people to wear face masks and limit their time spent outdoors to avoid inhaling smoke and ash.
Portugal heads into cooler days
Portugal is set for cooler weather in coming days after a spate of severe woodland fires. A national state of alert due to wildfires was enacted Aug. 2 and was due to end Sunday, a day before two Swedish firefighting planes were to arrive.
As in Spain, Portugal's resources have been stretched. On Sunday, more than 4,000 firefighters and more than 1,300 vehicles were deployed, as well as 17 aircraft, the country's Civil Protection Agency said.
The scorched area of forest in Portugal so far this year is 17 times higher than in 2024, according to preliminary calculations by the Institute for the Conservation of Nature and Forests, a government body.
Greece, Bulgaria, Montenegro and Albania have also requested help from the EU's firefighting force in recent days to deal with forest fires.
The force has already been activated as many times this year as in all of last year's summer fire season.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRY6-504H-00000-00Residents of Peñalba return home, but six districts of Peranzanes are evacuated2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisResidents of Peñalba return home, but six districts of Peranzanes are evacuated


The residents of Peñalba de Santiago have been able to return to their homes after the improvement in the evolution of the fire of Llamas de Cabrera, although they must remain under confinement, reported Saturday the Junta de Castilla y León, which has indicated, by contrast, that six districts of Peranzanes: Faro, Cariseda, Peranzanes, Trascastro, Chano and Guímara, have had to be evacuated.


In total, 838 people remain evacuated in 14 villages and another 235 confined in 11 localities, according to the last official balance.
Regarding the Llamas de Cabrera fire, also in El Bierzo, the operative has focused its efforts in the last hours in Espinoso de Compludo, with reproductions also in Corporales and in the surroundings of Peñalba and the evolution is considered "favorable and without risk of spreading".
The Fasgar fire, meanwhile, maintains the open focus that in recent days was declared in Colinas del Campo de Martín Moro Toledano.
The flames are advancing towards the valley of Tremor, where the lines of defense around an open pit mine are being reinforced with the aim of slowing their advance; in Colinas, the situation is practically stabilized between the Igüeña road.
Most worrying, in Anllares del Sil
The most worrying scenario continues in Anllares del Sil, where the fire is still active and out of control. A reproduction in Argayo del Sil that evolves towards the town -evacuated for three days-, has forced to maintain a strong deployment of aerial and terrestrial means.
In terms of communications, the LE-7311 (Nogar-Castrillo de Cabrera), the LE-4212 (Cariseda-Chano), the LE-5228 (Bouzas-Corporales) and the LE-5330 (Igüeña-Colinas) remain closed. On the other hand, the LE-2703, between Portilla de la Reina and Posada de Valdeón, has been reopened to traffic.
The Junta and the Subdelegación del Gobierno have asked the population not to approach the area of firefighting operations, since "it is not a spectacle and can be dangerous", and it can also hinder the firefighting operation.
They have also warned that in all the fires there are reproductions in the perimeter from midday due to the wind, with the risk of generating new outbreaks, so that the control of the fires will take several days and more in fires with such extensive perimeters with tens of kilometers.
Controlled the fire in Puercas (Zamora)
On the other hand, the forest fire of Puercas (Zamora) is already under control twelve days after starting and after having left four people seriously injured with burns and having devastated an area that according to calculations through the Copernicus satellite system may amount to about 6,200 hectares.
The fire fighting service of the Junta de Castilla y Leon has been controlled in recent hours this fire that started last August 11 by a recklessness and kept the level two in the Potential Severity Index until eight days ago and forced the evacuation of nine villages Zamorano.
This fire caused burns that keep four people hospitalized in serious or critical condition who were caught by the fire at the exit of their village, Abejera, when they were trying to leave the town in a vehicle that was completely burned.
The investigation of the Seprona of the Civil Guard has determined that the fire started in a plot in which there was accumulated waste and glass containers irregularly and that, due to high temperatures, the magnifying glass effect occurred and one of the crystals made the fire started.
The fire affected land in the environment of the Sierra de la Culebra de Zamora, an enclave of great environmental value in which in the summer of 2022 there were two major fires that burned more than 55,000 hectares.

urn:contentItem:6GJR-NP33-RRTN-P068-00000-00Feature: In Portugal's historic villages, flames test endurance and hope2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSFeature: In Portugal's historic villages, flames test endurance and hopeXun Wei

LISBON, Aug. 22 (Xinhua) -- Wildfires raging across central Portugal's Gardunha mountains have encircled several historic villages, forcing evacuations and leaving others under siege. Castelo Novo, one of Portugal's officially recognized "12 Historic Villages," known for its medieval ruins, picturesque scenery and cultural vitality that draw visitors year after year, is one of the hardest hit. Although the flames are now largely under control, firefighting crews remain stationed nearby, ready to respond to flare-ups at any moment.

On Thursday, as a Xinhua reporter entered the village, the acrid smell of smoke hung in the air, mingling with ash and haze. Flames have already licked the edge of the settlement; scorch marks scar the stone walls at the entrance, and the hills beyond lie charred, their blackened tree trunks leaning at awkward angles. From above, the scene resembles a quiet green oasis marooned in a desert of ash. Many residents have been evacuated, but some villagers and visitors remain. They gather in the local cafe, sipping coffee as if to ward off the bitter smoke that hangs over the square. Among them is Lopez, a Spanish tourist, who shrugged as he told Xinhua he never expected to encounter wildfires while traveling in Portugal. "Wildfires in Spain are even worse. So we've given up moving around - we'll just stay here a few days," he said. Eighty-year-old Lourenco Inacio's home sits at the edge of the village, separated from the flames only by a narrow road. A few days ago, when the fire was at its worst, flames shot six or seven meters high, he recalled. Driven by the strong wind, the wildfire surrounded the village in less than 30 minutes. Inacio lives beside a viewing terrace built for tourists. Standing there, one would normally see verdant hillsides stretching into the distance. Now, only scorched slopes remain, a landscape of ruin. Nights, residents say, are the most terrifying. Fires often reignite in the darkness, spreading from multiple directions. "Fear doesn't help," Inacio said. "You can't just watch everything burn away. I'll stay and fight until the end." Another villager, Antanio Barroso, also refuses to leave. His orchard has been destroyed, but his house still stands. Running his hand along a wall blackened by smoke, he said, "This house is all I've worked for in my life. I can't abandon it. I'll stay and fight alongside the firefighters." About 40 kilometers away, the village of Unhais da Serra is now another frontline. Nestled at the foot of Serra da Estrela, the highest peak on Portugal's mainland, it has seen its surrounding national forest reduced to ashes. Along the main road, dozens of fire trucks and more than a hundred firefighters are deployed to prevent flare-ups. Firefighter Gomes told Xinhua that crews from across the country have been battling here for a week, taking turns to rest wherever they can. According to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), wildfires in Portugal have scorched more than 278,000 hectares so far this year, second only to the record 563,000 hectares burned in 2017. In terms of land area affected, Portugal ranks first in Europe, with 3.03 percent of its territory burned - far above the long-term average of 1.05 percent. Portugal has been under nationwide alert since Aug. 3 due to extreme heat that has heightened wildfire risk. Two people have died in Portugal as a result of wildfires this year. With extreme heat persisting across the Iberian Peninsula, Portugal's wildfire threat remains acute. For the residents of Castelo Novo and Unhais da Serra, these ancient villages are more than just homes - they are history and heritage that must be defended. Enditem

urn:contentItem:6GRR-12W3-RSVJ-J3TY-00000-00Fires, storms, blazing temperatures forecast for the western U.S.2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisNATIONPg. A9Fires, storms, blazing temperatures forecast for the western U.S.Brian K. Sullivan Bloomberg NewsCamas

Smoke from the Gifford fire filters sunlight over the burned hills near the Cuyama Highway northwest of Los Angeles. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times/TNS)

4,277 blazes have charred 7.3 million acres this year
Fires, storms and the potential for near-record high temperatures across the western U.S. are in the offing for the coming week.


The Gifford Fire, about 125 miles northwest of Los Angeles, had burned 113,648 acres and was 21 percent contained through Saturday, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, commonly known as Cal Fire. So far, 809 people have been evacuated and the Los Padres National Forest was closed because of the flames. There are 3,935 fire crews and support staff on the scene, and at least seven have been injured, according to a joint statement by Cal Fire, the U.S. Forest Service and several local agencies.
The Gifford blaze is the largest of 14 fires across the state, according to Cal Fire.
Large wildfires in Colorado have also caused air quality to drop there, the U.S. National Weather Service said. Alerts are out across western portions of the state, including Vail, the agency said.
Meanwhile, smoke from forest fires in Canada has once again crossed into the U.S., causing air quality alerts to be posted in Minnesota and parts of Wisconsin, the National Weather Service said. There's also a dense smoke advisory in place across northeast parts of Montana. Across the border, air quality warnings are also in place for parts of Saskatchewan and Manitoba, Environment and Climate Change Canada said.
Across Canada, 714 active fires are burning, with 166 raging out of control, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. So far this year, 4,277 blazes have charred 7.3 million acres. In the U.S., there have been 42,854 fires reported on 3.5 million acres, the U.S. National Interagency Fire Center said. While the number of U.S. fires exceeds last year's 32,727 by this date, the acreage burned is less than the more than 5 million acres consumed a year ago.
U.S. heat advisories and extreme heat warnings are posted across parts of the west, including California, Nevada, Arizona, Oregon, Washington and Idaho.
In New York City and elsewhere in the Northeast, temperatures are set to rise. As many as 12 records may be tied or broken across the region in the coming week, the U.S. Weather Prediction Center said.
Flood watches have been posted across the Midwest, including Milwaukee, the weather service said. The Milwaukee River in Estabrook Park has risen more than 8 feet in the last day, cresting at a new record of 11.19 feet, the weather service said.  The following fields overflowed: REFERENCE = 08-12 A9 US-FIRES-STORMS-HEATBLO_A09

urn:contentItem:6GRR-12W3-RSVJ-J3R7-00000-00Fires, storms, blazing temperatures forecast for the western U.S.2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisNATIONPg. A9Fires, storms, blazing temperatures forecast for the western U.S.Brian K. Sullivan Bloomberg News

Smoke from the Gifford fire filters sunlight over the burned hills near the Cuyama Highway northwest of Los Angeles. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times/TNS)

4,277 blazes have charred 7.3 million acres this year
Fires, storms and the potential for near-record high temperatures across the western U.S. are in the offing for the coming week.


The Gifford Fire, about 125 miles northwest of Los Angeles, had burned 113,648 acres and was 21 percent contained through Saturday, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, commonly known as Cal Fire. So far, 809 people have been evacuated and the Los Padres National Forest was closed because of the flames. There are 3,935 fire crews and support staff on the scene, and at least seven have been injured, according to a joint statement by Cal Fire, the U.S. Forest Service and several local agencies.
The Gifford blaze is the largest of 14 fires across the state, according to Cal Fire.
Large wildfires in Colorado have also caused air quality to drop there, the U.S. National Weather Service said. Alerts are out across western portions of the state, including Vail, the agency said.
Meanwhile, smoke from forest fires in Canada has once again crossed into the U.S., causing air quality alerts to be posted in Minnesota and parts of Wisconsin, the National Weather Service said. There's also a dense smoke advisory in place across northeast parts of Montana. Across the border, air quality warnings are also in place for parts of Saskatchewan and Manitoba, Environment and Climate Change Canada said.
Across Canada, 714 active fires are burning, with 166 raging out of control, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. So far this year, 4,277 blazes have charred 7.3 million acres. In the U.S., there have been 42,854 fires reported on 3.5 million acres, the U.S. National Interagency Fire Center said. While the number of U.S. fires exceeds last year's 32,727 by this date, the acreage burned is less than the more than 5 million acres consumed a year ago.
U.S. heat advisories and extreme heat warnings are posted across parts of the west, including California, Nevada, Arizona, Oregon, Washington and Idaho.
In New York City and elsewhere in the Northeast, temperatures are set to rise. As many as 12 records may be tied or broken across the region in the coming week, the U.S. Weather Prediction Center said.
Flood watches have been posted across the Midwest, including Milwaukee, the weather service said. The Milwaukee River in Estabrook Park has risen more than 8 feet in the last day, cresting at a new record of 11.19 feet, the weather service said.  The following fields overflowed: REFERENCE = 08-12 A9 US-FIRES-STORMS-HEATBLO_A09

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9WM3-RY9B-V38T-00000-00Pediatricians ask children to wear masks in these cases because of what is happening in Spain: almost no one is spared2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisPediatricians ask children to wear masks in these cases because of what is happening in Spain: almost no one is spared


The Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) has warned this Tuesday that the impact of smoke from forest fires currently affecting Spain has health risks for children and adolescents, even hundreds of kilometers away, because atmospheric currents can carry pollutant particles present in the smoke to populations that do not have a fire in their vicinity.


In depth
The agency's Committee on Environmental Health (CSM-AEP) has prepared a report detailing that this smoke contains fine and ultrafine particulate matter (PM2.5), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocyanic acid (HCN) and other potentially carcinogenic organic compounds, whose exposure can have immediate and long-term effects.
In the short term, their inhalation can cause an aggravation of chronic respiratory diseases (asthma, allergic rhinitis), an increase in acute respiratory infections, eye and mucosal irritation (conjunctivitis, coughing, throat clearing) and carbon monoxide or cyanide poisoning; while in the long term, repeated exposure can contribute to the development of respiratory, cardiovascular or immunological diseases, in addition to possible neurotoxic effects that alter neurological development.
Exposure to this type of smoke can also affect children's mental health and psychological well-being, and can lead to anxiety and stress, both in the short and long term.
Pediatricians have also shown their concern about the fact that the number of forest fires and the area burned in Spain has increased "significantly" in recent years, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), a trend that is linked to climate change and is expected to continue to intensify.
"Added to these environmental risks is the special vulnerability of childhood and adolescence, both because of their developing physiology and their behavioral exposure: they breathe more air per kilogram of weight than adults, tend to spend more time outdoors and depend on adults to keep them safe," the pediatricians added.
More details
For all these reasons, the CSM-AEP has published a document in which it has included a series of measures for prevention and reduction of the risks associated with this type of smoke, and in which it has included the importance of consulting official alerts, following the warnings of Civil Protection and security forces and contacting 112 in case of signs of fire or presence of smoke.
Similarly, it has recommended monitoring air quality through the Air Quality Index viewer of the Ministry for Ecological Transition (MITECO) or its mobile application.
The organization has also advised improving the indoor air in each home, for which windows and doors should be kept closed, using purifiers with appropriate filters (ISO16890 ePM1 or higher) and putting the air conditioner in recirculation mode.
To avoid additional sources of contamination at home, it is necessary to avoid smoking or using combustion systems (wood, gas, candles, barbecues) during episodes of high contamination.
The use of FFP2 masks can also help reduce exposure to particulate matter, and their use is recommended for children from the age of two, provided they can tolerate them adequately.
To cope with fires, pediatricians have stressed the importance of being prepared for emergencies and of having basic supplies (such as water or non-perishable food) and rescue medication in case of chronic pathologies such as asthma. In the event that the authorities recommend evacuation or in the case of not being able to guarantee a safe environment at home, evacuation should be carried out to authorized places, with air conditioning and filtered air.
They have also reported that dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty breathing or behavioral changes may be signs of possible poisoning by carbon monoxide and / or hydrogen cyanide, cases in which should go "immediately" to an emergency room. In case of doubt, the health center or the Pediatric Environmental Health Unit (PEHSU) of reference can be consulted.
Before returning to an affected area, it is important to check both the safety of the home, access to basic services such as water or electricity, and to clean up "properly" before exposing children to the environment.
Finally, pediatricians have insisted on the importance of taking care of mental health, since fires can have long-lasting psychological effects on children, which is why they have recommended observing emotional or behavioral changes and, if necessary, seeking professional support.

urn:contentItem:6G9H-YGJ3-S6N0-K553-00000-00Fire restrictions take effect in the Gifford Pinchot National Forest2025-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSFire restrictions take effect in the Gifford Pinchot National ForestThe Chronicle, Centralia, Wash.

Jul. 18—Due to increased risk of wildfires, the Gifford Pinchot National Forest fire managers have issued restrictions on campfires, smoking and other activities within the forest.

The restrictions went into effect on July 17, according to a news release from the U.S. Forest Service.

Restrictions include:

—Building, maintaining, attending or using a fire, campfire or stove fire, including a charcoal fire and pellet fire on all National Forest lands. Portable cooking stoves, lanterns and heating devices using liquefied or bottled fuel, such as propane, are allowed as they can be switched off instantly.

—Smoking, except within an enclosed vehicle or building, a designated campground or while stopped in an area at least 3 feet in diameter that is barren or cleared of all flammable material.

—Possessing, discharging or using any kind of firework or other pyrotechnic device is prohibited year-round on national forest lands.

—Operating or using any internal or external combustion engine without a spark arresting device properly installed, maintained and in effective working order.

Nearly nine out of 10 wildfires nationwide are human caused and can be prevented. Everyone can do their part to help prevent wildfires. Smokey Bear's message of preventing unwanted human-caused ignitions is more relevant today than ever before as more people live closer to wildlands and recreate outdoors, the Forest Service stated in the release.

urn:contentItem:6FDD-PTD3-RRTB-31MB-00000-00Researchers at IPB University Report Research in Environment and Natural Resources (Application of Random Forest Algorithm to Analyze the Confidence Level of Forest Fire Hotspots in Riau Peatland)2025-03-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:06ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT - ENVIRONMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCESResearchers at IPB University Report Research in Environment and Natural Resources (Application of Random Forest Algorithm to Analyze the Confidence Level of Forest Fire Hotspots in Riau Peatland)


2025 MAR 24 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on environment and natural resources. According to news reporting from Bogor, Indonesia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires pose a significant challenge in Riau Province, Indonesia, especially in peatland areas."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from IPB University: "This study employs the Random Forest (RF) algorithm to analyze the confidence levels of hotspots, aiming to predict potential fire occurrences and improve fire management strategies. The research focuses on peatlands spanning 3.86 million ha, using key variables such as NDVI, surface temperature, and peat thickness derived from satellite data. The model achieved an average AUC of 0.732 and a classification accuracy of 70.3%, with medium-confidence hotspots demonstrating the best predictive performance (AUC: 0.707, F1-score: 0.804). However, the model struggled with low-confidence hotspots, reflecting challenges in distinguishing less prominent patterns in the data. Compared to other methods, RF demonstrates strong potential in handling complex environmental datasets, making it a valuable tool for hotspot prediction."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study contributes to understanding forest fire risks in peatlands and provides actionable insights for improving preparedness and mitigation efforts."
For more information on this research see: Application of Random Forest Algorithm to Analyze the Confidence Level of Forest Fire Hotspots in Riau Peatland. Journal of Natural Resources and Environmental Management, 2025,15(2). (Journal of Natural Resources and Environmental Management - http://journal.ipb.ac.id/index.php/jpsl). The publisher for Journal of Natural Resources and Environmental Management is Bogor Agricultural University.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.29244/jpsl.15.2.255.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Mitra Unik, Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences, IPB University, Bogor, 16680, Indonesia. Additional authors for this research include Imas Sukaesih Sitanggang, Lailan Syaufina, I Nengah Surati Jaya.
Keywords for this news article include: IPB University, Bogor, Indonesia, Asia, Algorithms, Environment, Environment and Natural Resources.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC
